title: VEGOILS-Palm hits over 1 month-high; stronger ringgit caps gains
text:
VEGOILS-Palm hits over 1 month-high; stronger ringgit caps gains

SINGAPORE, Oct 21 (Reuters) - Malaysian palm oil futures rose for the fifth consecutive session on Monday to hit a more than one-month high, tracking gains in rival oils, but a stronger ringgit and potential trade sanctions limited gains.

The benchmark palm oil contract for January delivery FCPOc3 on the Bursa Malaysia Derivatives Exchange rose 0.1% to 2,290 ringgit ($547.39) per tonne by midday, its highest since Sept. 17.

Dalian's January palm oil contract DCPF0 was last up 0.6% on Monday, while the January soyoil contract DBYF0 was 0.1% higher.

Elsewhere, U.S. soyoil futures on the Chicago Board of Trade BOc2 were up 0.2%.

Palm oil is affected by price movements in related oils as they compete for share in the global vegetable oils market.

The gains were limited by a stronger ringgit, which last fell 0.1% against the dollar, making the edible oil more expensive for holders of foreign currencies.

Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said on Monday his exports-reliant country could be hit with trade sanctions, also contributing to limiting palm's gains. did not mention the sanctions' source but complained of being bullied by powerful nations, referring to a campaign by European countries against palm oil.

There are also concerns that India, the biggest buyer of Malaysian palm oil, would restrict imports of the product due to a diplomatic row over comments made by Mahathir on New Delhi's recent actions in the disputed South Asian region of Kashmir.

Palm oil may test a resistance at 2,317 ringgit per tonne, a break above which could lead to a gain to 2,364 ringgit, said Reuters analyst Wang Tao. TECH/C

"The market is not reacting so strongly to Mahathir's comments, but maybe that's why it's also unable to test resistance at 2,300 ringgit," a Kuala Lumpur-based trader said.
